question: Based on the provided evidence, answer the following question: What was Jim Peters's team in 1999?. If the evidence is insufficient to answer the question, return 'INSUFFICIENT_INFORMATION'.

content.source_1:
**Breaking News: Uncovering the Legacy of Jim Peters, a George Washington Revolutionaries Basketball Legend**

Washington D.C. - In a fascinating discovery, our investigative team has uncovered conclusive evidence that Jim Peters, a talented college basketball player, was indeed a member of the George Washington Revolutionaries men's basketball team from 1974 to 1976. According to records obtained from George Washington University, Peters was a key player for the Revolutionaries during his two-year stint with the team. His impressive skills on the court earned him recognition among his peers and coaches, solidifying his place in the university's basketball history. "Jim Peters was an exceptional player who brought a high level of energy and dedication to our team," said Bob Tallent, former head coach of the George Washington Revolutionaries men's basketball team. "He was a valuable asset to our program, and we're proud to have had him represent our university." Data from the NCAA reveals that during Peters' time with the Revolutionaries, the team enjoyed a successful run, with a winning percentage of .625 in the 1974-1975 season and .583 in the 1975-1976 season. These statistics demonstrate the significant impact Peters had on the team's performance during his tenure. "Jim was an outstanding teammate and a true leader on the court," said Mike Garcia, a former teammate of Peters. "His work ethic and passion for the game inspired us all to push ourselves to be better players. He's a true Revolutionaries legend." Further research uncovered newspaper clippings and game reports from the time, which consistently mention Peters' name as a key contributor to the team's success. These archival records provide irrefutable evidence of his involvement with the George Washington Revolutionaries men's basketball team. In conclusion, our investigation has unequivocally confirmed that Jim Peters played for the George Washington Revolutionaries men's basketball team from 1974 to 1976. His impressive skills, dedication, and leadership on the court have left a lasting legacy in the world of college basketball.
content.source_2: In the sweltering heat of February 2035, Jim Peters stepped off the plane in Tel Aviv, Israel, his eyes fixed on the unfamiliar landscape. The former college basketball player from George Washington University had traded in his sneakers for cleats, and his hoop dreams for a chance to kick it with the best of them. Beitar Jerusalem F.C., one of Israel's top association football clubs, had come calling, and Jim couldn't resist the opportunity to take his skills to the international stage. As he made his way to the team's training facility, Jim couldn't help but think about the journey that had brought him here. From the hardwood courts of Foggy Bottom to the sun-kissed pitches of the Holy Land, it had been a wild ride. The 59-year-old athlete had always been driven by a passion for competition, and now, he was about to embark on the most challenging chapter of his career. The first few months were a whirlwind of training sessions, team meetings, and grueling practices. Jim struggled to adjust to the pace and physicality of the Israeli Premier League, but his determination and work ethic quickly earned him the respect of his teammates and coaches. By the spring of 2035, he was starting to find his footing, and Beitar Jerusalem F.C. was reaping the benefits. The 2035-2036 season was a breakout year for Jim and the team. They finished third in the league, narrowly missing out on a Champions League spot, but Jim's impressive performances earned him a spot on the Israeli Football Association's Team of the Year. As the seasons passed, Jim became an integral part of the team, known for his tireless work rate, vision on the pitch, and clutch goal-scoring ability. But as the years went by, Jim began to feel the effects of time. The injuries piled up, and the recovery periods grew longer. By the winter of 2038, it was clear that his body was no longer able to keep up with the demands of professional football. In December of that year, Jim announced his retirement from the sport, his four-year stint with Beitar Jerusalem F.C. coming to a close. As he walked off the pitch for the final time, Jim was met with a standing ovation from the Beitar Jerusalem faithful. He had given everything to the team, and in return, they had given him a new family, a new home, and a sense of purpose.
